Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> If all your Hush is on an exchange, or the web wallet, you are not affected by the Sprout issue. Only people that made special "shielded" transactions and have funds in addresses starting with *z* are affected. Currently ~1.1% of total supply

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> if all your funds are in taddrs, you are fine. It's not a bad idea to sweep funds into 1 or a few addresses, versus having funds in hundreds of addresses. Mostly this will only effect miners, who sometimes have many addresses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <NaturalCoin--Macro-Pool.com> Ok cool. I typically use one or two addresses anyway to keep things organized.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it's good to have different buckets for different uses, but not too many buckets üòÉ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> soon, super-fast Sapling zaddrs will only take a few seconds to make transactions, and it will be viable to do that on mobile devices. That was never a possibility with it taking 45 minutes and gigs of RAM to make a Sprout shielded xtn

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I paused HushList protocol stuff because Sprout was too slow, so all of this work unlocks those possibilities again. That is actually what I want to work on, HushList protocol stuff. But it just wasn't viable on Sprout.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @bastos lots of stuff will be coming in 2019, and support for messaging will be included in a full node GUI wallet. Right now that would be the hush-ng codebase (updated for our new chain), but I am still deciding if a QT-based wallet is a better idea

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> once we are updated to Sapling, messaging becomes super-fast.  In theory, it will take a few seconds to generate and about 2.5 minutes to be confirmed in a block. But confirmations are less important for most messages. The message "Thanks for the gift, see you next time" does not need confirmations, but "SELL ALL ASSETS" would be something you wanted notarized confirmations for.  51% attacks don't make much sense against messages/memos, except to deny them. A 51% attacker can act as a censor, and block transactions from anybody or everybody, if it wants. But it has to spend lots of time/money to do that, so it would only make sense to do that strategically.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Sneak preview of one cryptocondition smart contract that we are enabling on the new HUSH AC: Heir : https://github.com/KomodoPlatform/developer-docs/blob/gcharang/docs/basic-docs/cryptoconditions/cc-heir.md

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it allows you to do cryptocoin inheritance. If you don't make any transactions for X time period, another address is allowed to use the funds, basically.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> right now it's all CLI based, but GUIs are coming. KMD is working on so many cool cryptocondition projects, Heir is just one

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> the bad bug came from Zcash itself, all Zcash forks were affected by this, to clarify. It's not a bug specific to Hush

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Now with just the command `git merge jl777/jl777` I merged in 51 commits from jl777 into our new Hush codebase, in a few seconds. That is the power of becoming a KMD AC

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I am working hard to come up with just the right chain parameters to make the new Hush blockchain!  I just wrote a script that makes things work exactly the same as before, i.e. `./src/hushd` will start the Hush daemon, so there is nothing new to learn when people upgrade to the new Hush. I am trying to make the transition as easy as possible for mining pools, exchanges and everybody that runs a full node
